flashcards.definition: A symbol, usually a letter, that represents a number in mathematical expressions or equations.
A number that is multiplied by a variable in an algebraic expression.
A mathematical statement that asserts the equality of two expressions.
A combination of numbers, variables, and operators (such as +, -, *, /) without an equality sign.
A mathematical statement that compares two expressions and shows that they are not equal.
The central argument or main point of an essay or research paper.
The quality of being logically connected and consistent within a piece of writing.
Words or phrases that link different ideas or sections of writing.
The attitude or approach that the author takes toward the essay’s main theme.
The group of readers or viewers that the writer is addressing in their work.
A figure formed by two rays, called the sides of the angle, sharing a common endpoint called the vertex.
A plane figure with at least three straight sides and angles, typically five or more.
Lines in a plane that are equidistant and never intersect.
Two figures or objects are congruent if they have the same shape and size.
The continuous line forming the boundary of a closed geometric figure.
The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences in a language.
The choice and use of words and phrases in speech or writing.
An idea or feeling that a word invokes in addition to its literal or primary meaning.
The literal or primary meaning of a word, in contrast to the feelings or ideas that the word suggests.
A figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.
A trigonometric function of an angle defined as the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle.
A trigonometric function of an angle defined as the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle.
A trigonometric function of an angle defined as the ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent side in a right triangle.
A fundamental relation in Euclidean geometry among the three sides of a right triangle.
A circle with a radius of one, centered at the origin of a coordinate plane, used to define trigonometric functions.
An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object.
The speed of something in a given direction.
The rate of change of velocity per unit of time.
Work is done when a force is applied to an object and the object moves.
The capacity to do work or produce heat.
The supreme law of the United States, establishing the national government and fundamental laws.
A war between the Northern and Southern states of the U.S. from 1861-1865.
The movement to end slavery.
The first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution that guarantee individual rights.
The 19th-century doctrine that the expansion of the U.S. throughout the American continents was both justified and inevitable.
The smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.
Two or more atoms bonded together, representing the smallest fundamental unit of a chemical compound.
A substance made up of two or more different types of atoms bonded together.
An atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of one or more electrons.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.
One of the seven large landmasses on the Earth.
An imaginary line around the middle of the Earth, equally distant from the North and South Poles.
Half of the Earth, usually divided into Northern and Southern or Eastern and Western.
The distance north or south of the equator, measured in degrees.
The distance east or west of the prime meridian, measured in degrees.
The basic structural, functional, and biological unit of all living organisms.
The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information in all living organisms.
A community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
The process by which different kinds of living organisms are thought to have developed and diversified from earlier forms during the history of the earth.
The total amount of a product or service that is available to consumers.
The desire of purchasers, consumers, or clients for a particular good or service.
A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.
The total value of goods produced and services provided in a country during one year.
An economic system in which production and prices are determined by unrestricted competition between privately owned businesses.
The occurrence of the same letter or sound at the beginning of adjacent or closely connected words.
A contrast between expectation and reality, often highlighting the opposite of what is expected.
A literary device used to give an indication or hint of what is to come later in the story.
A figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.
The attribution of a personal nature or human characteristics to something non-human.
A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations.
A particular way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently.
A programming structure that repeats a sequence of instructions until a specific condition is met.
A storage location paired with an associated symbolic name, which contains some known or unknown quantity or information.
A block of code designed to perform a particular task, and is executed when called.
The variety of plant and animal life in the world or in a particular habitat.
A long-term change in the average weather patterns that have come to define Earth’s local, regional, and global climates.
Avoidance of the depletion of natural resources in order to maintain an ecological balance.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
Energy from a source that is not depleted when used, such as wind or solar power.
A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust, held together by gravitational attraction.
A region of space having a gravitational field so intense that no matter or radiation can escape.
A cloud of gas and dust in space, often where stars are born.
A unit of astronomical distance equivalent to the distance that light travels in one year.
A stellar explosion that occurs at the end of a star's life cycle.
